questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I:
(A) Porifera
(B) Cnidaria
(C) Platyhelminthes
(D) Annelida

Column II:
(i) Flame cells
(ii) Cnidoblasts
(iii) Nephridia
(iv) Spongocoel

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Porifera has spongocoel (central cavity), Cnidaria has cnidoblasts (stinging cells), Platyhelminthes has flame cells (excretory structures), and Annelida has nephridia (excretory organs). These are characteristic features of each phylum as described in NCERT Chapter 4.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Phylum):
(A) Arthropoda
(B) Mollusca
(C) Echinodermata
(D) Hemichordata

Column II (Larva):
(i) Tornaria
(ii) Trochophore
(iii) Bipinnaria
(iv) Nauplius

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Arthropoda has nauplius larva (e.g., in crustaceans), Mollusca has trochophore larva, Echinodermata has bipinnaria larva (in starfish), and Hemichordata has tornaria larva. These larval forms are key identification features. NCERT Chapter 4.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Animal):
(A) Asterias
(B) Balanoglossus
(C) Nereis
(D) Pila

Column II (Phylum):
(i) Hemichordata
(ii) Annelida
(iii) Mollusca
(iv) Echinodermata

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Asterias (starfish) belongs to Echinodermata, Balanoglossus (acorn worm) to Hemichordata, Nereis (sandworm) to Annelida, and Pila (apple snail) to Mollusca. These are classic examples given in NCERT Chapter 4.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Class):
(A) Chondrichthyes
(B) Osteichthyes
(C) Amphibia
(D) Reptilia

Column II (Feature):
(i) Three-chambered heart with incomplete septum in ventricle
(ii) Cartilaginous endoskeleton
(iii) Air bladder for buoyancy
(iv) Three-chambered heart

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Chondrichthyes have cartilaginous endoskeleton, Osteichthyes have air bladder for buoyancy, Amphibia have three-chambered heart, and Reptilia have three-chambered heart with incomplete septum in ventricle (except crocodiles which have four-chambered). NCERT Chapter 4.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Body feature):
(A) Ctenophora
(B) Aschelminthes
(C) Arthropoda
(D) Chordata

Column II (Body cavity type):
(i) Pseudocoelomate
(ii) Acoelomate
(iii) Eucoelomate — schizocoelous
(iv) Eucoelomate — enterocoelous

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Ctenophora are acoelomates (no body cavity), Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomates (false coelom), Arthropoda are eucoelomates with schizocoelous coelom (formed by splitting of mesoderm), and Chordata are eucoelomates with enterocoelous coelom (formed from gut pouches). NCERT Chapter 4.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Division):
(A) Bryophyta
(B) Pteridophyta
(C) Gymnospermae
(D) Angiospermae

Column II (Feature):
(i) Double fertilization
(ii) Naked seeds
(iii) Dominant sporophyte with vascular tissue
(iv) Dominant gametophyte

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Bryophyta has dominant gametophyte (plant body is gametophytic), Pteridophyta has dominant sporophyte with vascular tissue (first vascular plants), Gymnospermae has naked seeds (not enclosed in fruit), and Angiospermae has double fertilization (unique feature). NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Algae):
(A) Chlorophyceae
(B) Phaeophyceae
(C) Rhodophyceae
(D) Xanthophyceae

Column II (Stored food / Pigment):
(i) Floridean starch, r-phycoerythrin
(ii) Starch, chlorophyll a and b
(iii) Laminarin, fucoxanthin
(iv) Oils, xanthophyll

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Chlorophyceae (green algae) store starch and have chlorophyll a and b. Phaeophyceae (brown algae) store laminarin and have fucoxanthin. Rhodophyceae (red algae) store floridean starch and have r-phycoerythrin. Xanthophyceae store oils and have xanthophyll. NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Bryophyte):
(A) Funaria
(B) Marchantia
(C) Sphagnum
(D) Anthoceros

Column II (Common name / Feature):
(i) Hornwort
(ii) Peat moss
(iii) Liverwort with gemma cups
(iv) Common moss with peristome teeth

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Funaria is a common moss with peristome teeth on its capsule. Marchantia is a liverwort known for gemma cups (asexual reproduction). Sphagnum is peat moss (economically important). Anthoceros is a hornwort (horn-shaped sporophyte). NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Gymnosperm):
(A) Cycas
(B) Pinus
(C) Ginkgo
(D) Sequoia

Column II (Feature):
(i) Living fossil
(ii) Tallest tree genus
(iii) Coralloid roots with cyanobacteria
(iv) Needle-like leaves with resin canals

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Cycas has coralloid roots harbouring nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria. Pinus has needle-like leaves with resin canals. Ginkgo biloba is a living fossil (sole surviving species of its order). Sequoia (redwood) is the tallest tree genus. NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Kingdom):
(A) Monera
(B) Protista
(C) Fungi
(D) Plantae

Column II (Cell wall composition):
(i) Cellulose
(ii) Chitin
(iii) Peptidoglycan (in bacteria)
(iv) Absent in many / silica in diatoms

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Monera (bacteria) have cell walls made of peptidoglycan. Protista may lack cell walls or have silica (diatoms). Fungi have chitin in their cell walls. Plantae have cellulose cell walls. NCERT Chapter 2.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Disease):
(A) Black rust of wheat
(B) Ergot of rye
(C) Late blight of potato
(D) Brown rot of fruits

Column II (Pathogen):
(i) Phytophthora infestans
(ii) Puccinia graminis
(iii) Claviceps purpurea
(iv) Monilinia fructicola

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Black rust of wheat is caused by Puccinia graminis (Basidiomycete). Ergot of rye is caused by Claviceps purpurea (Ascomycete). Late blight of potato is caused by Phytophthora infestans (Oomycete). Brown rot of fruits is caused by Monilinia fructicola. NCERT Chapter 2.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Organism):
(A) Amoeba
(B) Paramoecium
(C) Euglena
(D) Plasmodium

Column II (Feature):
(i) Mixotrophic nutrition
(ii) Pseudopodia for movement
(iii) Obligate parasite causing malaria
(iv) Cilia for locomotion

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Amoeba moves using pseudopodia. Paramoecium uses cilia for locomotion. Euglena shows mixotrophic nutrition (autotrophic in light, heterotrophic in dark). Plasmodium is an obligate parasite causing malaria. NCERT Chapter 2.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Modification):
(A) Stem tendril
(B) Stem thorn
(C) Phylloclade
(D) Bulbil

Column II (Example):
(i) Opuntia
(ii) Agave
(iii) Citrus
(iv) Passiflora

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Passiflora has stem tendrils (axillary buds modified for climbing). Citrus has stem thorns (axillary buds modified for protection). Opuntia has phylloclades (flattened stems performing photosynthesis). Agave produces bulbils (vegetative buds for propagation). NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Inflorescence type):
(A) Raceme
(B) Cymose (Helicoid cyme)
(C) Capitulum (Head)
(D) Spadix

Column II (Example):
(i) Sunflower
(ii) Banana
(iii) Mustard
(iv) Hamelia

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Mustard has raceme inflorescence (flowers on pedicels along an axis). Hamelia has helicoid cyme (cymose). Sunflower has capitulum/head (characteristic of Asteraceae). Banana has spadix (fleshy axis with spathe). NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Family):
(A) Fabaceae
(B) Solanaceae
(C) Liliaceae
(D) Brassicaceae

Column II (Fruit type):
(i) Berry
(ii) Siliqua
(iii) Legume / Pod
(iv) Capsule

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Fabaceae produces legume/pod fruits. Solanaceae produces berry (e.g., tomato). Liliaceae produces capsule. Brassicaceae produces siliqua (a special fruit type). NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Tissue):
(A) Collenchyma
(B) Sclerenchyma
(C) Parenchyma
(D) Aerenchyma

Column II (Feature):
(i) Large air cavities for buoyancy
(ii) Uniformly thick, lignified walls; dead at maturity
(iii) Cellulose thickening at corners; living
(iv) Thin-walled, isodiametric; living

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Collenchyma has cellulose thickening at corners and is living (provides flexibility). Sclerenchyma has uniformly thick, lignified walls and is dead at maturity (provides mechanical support). Parenchyma is thin-walled, isodiametric, and living. Aerenchyma has large air cavities providing buoyancy to aquatic plants. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Vascular bundle type):
(A) Conjoint, open
(B) Conjoint, closed
(C) Radial
(D) Concentric (amphicribal)

Column II (Found in):
(i) Roots of angiosperms
(ii) Monocot stem
(iii) Dicot stem
(iv) Fern rhizome

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Dicot stems have conjoint, open vascular bundles (cambium present, allowing secondary growth). Monocot stems have conjoint, closed bundles (no cambium). Angiosperm roots have radial vascular bundles (xylem and phloem on separate radii). Fern rhizomes have concentric amphicribal bundles (phloem surrounds xylem). NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Secondary growth structure):
(A) Cork cambium
(B) Vascular cambium
(C) Heartwood
(D) Sapwood

Column II (Function / Feature):
(i) Conducts water and minerals; living
(ii) Produces secondary xylem and phloem
(iii) Dark-coloured; non-functional; filled with tannins
(iv) Produces cork (phellem) and phelloderm

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Cork cambium (phellogen) produces cork outward and phelloderm inward. Vascular cambium produces secondary xylem inward and secondary phloem outward. Heartwood is dark, non-functional, filled with tannins/resins. Sapwood is the outer, living, water-conducting wood. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Enzyme):
(A) Lipase
(B) Nuclease
(C) Protease
(D) Amylase

Column II (Substrate):
(i) Starch
(ii) Proteins
(iii) Lipids / Fats
(iv) Nucleic acids

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Lipase acts on lipids/fats, nuclease acts on nucleic acids, protease acts on proteins, and amylase acts on starch. Enzymes are named after their substrates with the suffix '-ase'. NCERT Chapter 9.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Vitamin):
(A) Thiamine (B1)
(B) Ascorbic acid (C)
(C) Tocopherol (E)
(D) Calciferol (D)

Column II (Deficiency disease):
(i) Rickets
(ii) Scurvy
(iii) Beriberi
(iv) Sterility / Muscular dystrophy

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Thiamine (B1) deficiency causes beriberi. Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) deficiency causes scurvy. Tocopherol (Vitamin E) deficiency causes sterility and muscular dystrophy. Calciferol (Vitamin D) deficiency causes rickets. NCERT Chapter 9.

questions.topic: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants
questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Biomolecule):
(A) Cellulose
(B) Glycogen
(C) Chitin
(D) Starch

Column II (Found in):
(i) Plant cell wall
(ii) Fungal cell wall
(iii) Plant storage (amyloplasts)
(iv) Animal liver and muscle

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Cellulose is the structural polysaccharide in plant cell walls. Glycogen is the storage carbohydrate in animal liver and muscle. Chitin forms the cell wall of fungi and exoskeleton of arthropods. Starch is stored in amyloplasts of plants. NCERT Chapter 9.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Blood cell type):
(A) Neutrophils
(B) Eosinophils
(C) Basophils
(D) Lymphocytes

Column II (Function):
(i) Adaptive immunity (B and T cells)
(ii) Phagocytosis of bacteria (most abundant WBC)
(iii) Allergic response; resist parasitic infections
(iv) Release histamine and serotonin; inflammatory response

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Neutrophils are the most abundant WBCs and phagocytose bacteria. Eosinophils resist parasitic infections and are involved in allergic responses. Basophils release histamine and serotonin in inflammatory responses. Lymphocytes (B and T cells) mediate adaptive/specific immunity. NCERT Chapter 18.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (ECG wave):
(A) P wave
(B) QRS complex
(C) T wave
(D) P-Q interval

Column II (Event):
(i) Ventricular repolarization
(ii) Atrial depolarization
(iii) Ventricular depolarization
(iv) AV nodal delay

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: P wave represents atrial depolarization. QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization. T wave represents ventricular repolarization. P-Q interval represents AV nodal delay (time for impulse to travel from SA node through AV node). NCERT Chapter 18.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Enzyme):
(A) Pepsin
(B) Trypsin
(C) Ptyalin (Salivary amylase)
(D) Lipase (Pancreatic)

Column II (Secreted by / Acts in):
(i) Salivary glands; buccal cavity
(ii) Gastric glands; stomach
(iii) Pancreas; duodenum (on fats)
(iv) Pancreas; duodenum (on proteins)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Pepsin is secreted by gastric glands and acts in the stomach on proteins in acidic pH. Trypsin is secreted by pancreas and acts in duodenum on proteins in alkaline pH. Ptyalin (salivary amylase) is secreted by salivary glands and acts in the buccal cavity on starch. Pancreatic lipase acts in duodenum on fats. NCERT Chapter 16.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (GI region):
(A) Stomach
(B) Duodenum
(C) Ileum
(D) Large intestine

Column II (Key function):
(i) Maximum absorption of digested food
(ii) Protein digestion by pepsin; HCl secretion
(iii) Absorption of water, electrolytes; bacterial fermentation
(iv) Receives bile and pancreatic juice

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Stomach secretes HCl and pepsin for protein digestion. Duodenum receives bile and pancreatic juice. Ileum is the site of maximum absorption of digested food. Large intestine absorbs water and electrolytes and houses bacteria for fermentation. NCERT Chapter 16.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Feature):
(A) DNA
(B) mRNA
(C) tRNA
(D) rRNA

Column II (Characteristic):
(i) Cloverleaf shape; carries amino acids
(ii) Double-stranded helix; deoxyribose sugar
(iii) Forms ribosomes along with proteins
(iv) Carries genetic code from DNA to ribosome

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: DNA is a double-stranded helix with deoxyribose sugar. mRNA carries genetic code from nucleus to ribosome (messenger). tRNA has cloverleaf shape and carries amino acids to ribosome (transfer). rRNA is a structural component of ribosomes along with proteins. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Experiment / Scientist):
(A) Griffith
(B) Hershey and Chase
(C) Meselson and Stahl
(D) Beadle and Tatum

Column II (Contribution):
(i) Semi-conservative replication of DNA
(ii) One gene - one enzyme hypothesis
(iii) Transforming principle (bacterial transformation)
(iv) DNA is the genetic material (using bacteriophage T2)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Griffith discovered the transforming principle using Streptococcus pneumoniae. Hershey and Chase proved DNA is genetic material using bacteriophage T2 with radioactive labelling. Meselson and Stahl proved semi-conservative replication using heavy nitrogen (N-15). Beadle and Tatum proposed one gene-one enzyme hypothesis using Neurospora. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Lac operon component):
(A) Structural gene z
(B) Structural gene y
(C) Structural gene a
(D) Operator gene

Column II (Product / Function):
(i) Transacetylase
(ii) Beta-galactosidase
(iii) Permease
(iv) Binding site for repressor protein

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Gene z codes for beta-galactosidase (cleaves lactose into glucose and galactose). Gene y codes for permease (facilitates lactose entry). Gene a codes for transacetylase. The operator gene is the binding site for repressor protein. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Codon):
(A) AUG
(B) UAA
(C) UAG
(D) UGA

Column II (Function / Name):
(i) Amber (stop codon)
(ii) Ochre (stop codon)
(iii) Opal / Umber (stop codon)
(iv) Start codon (codes for methionine)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: AUG is the universal start codon coding for methionine (also formyl-methionine in prokaryotes). UAA is the ochre stop codon. UAG is the amber stop codon. UGA is the opal/umber stop codon. These three codons do not code for any amino acid. NCERT Chapter 6.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Genetic disorder):
(A) Down syndrome
(B) Turner syndrome
(C) Klinefelter syndrome
(D) Phenylketonuria

Column II (Cause / Feature):
(i) Autosomal recessive; phenylalanine accumulation
(ii) Trisomy 21 (47 chromosomes)
(iii) 44+XXY; male with gynaecomastia
(iv) 44+X0; short stature, sterile female

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is trisomy 21 (2n+1 = 47). Turner syndrome is 44+X0 (monosomy X); short stature, sterile female. Klinefelter syndrome is 44+XXY; male with gynaecomastia and sterility. Phenylketonuria is autosomal recessive with phenylalanine accumulation in brain. NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Type of inheritance):
(A) Incomplete dominance
(B) Co-dominance
(C) Epistasis
(D) Pleiotropy

Column II (Example):
(i) ABO blood groups (IA and IB)
(ii) Sickle cell anaemia (one gene, many effects)
(iii) Flower colour in snapdragon (Antirrhinum)
(iv) Coat colour in mice (agouti locus)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Incomplete dominance is shown by flower colour in snapdragon (red x white = pink). Co-dominance is shown by ABO blood groups where IA and IB are co-dominant. Epistasis is shown by coat colour in mice (agouti gene). Pleiotropy is shown by sickle cell anaemia where one gene affects multiple traits. NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Blood group):
(A) A
(B) B
(C) AB
(D) O

Column II (Genotype / Antibodies):
(i) IAIB; no antibodies (universal recipient)
(ii) IAIA or IAi; anti-B antibodies
(iii) IBIB or IBi; anti-A antibodies
(iv) ii; anti-A and anti-B antibodies (universal donor)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Blood group A has genotype IAIA or IAi and produces anti-B antibodies. Blood group B has genotype IBIB or IBi and produces anti-A antibodies. Blood group AB has genotype IAIB, produces no antibodies (universal recipient). Blood group O has genotype ii, produces both anti-A and anti-B antibodies (universal donor). NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Disorder):
(A) Haemophilia
(B) Colour blindness
(C) Sickle cell anaemia
(D) Thalassemia

Column II (Inheritance pattern / Defect):
(i) Autosomal recessive; defective globin chain synthesis
(ii) X-linked recessive; defective clotting factor VIII
(iii) Autosomal recessive; single base substitution (GAG to GUG)
(iv) X-linked recessive; defective cone cells in eye

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Haemophilia is X-linked recessive due to defective clotting factor VIII. Colour blindness is X-linked recessive due to defective cone cells. Sickle cell anaemia is autosomal recessive due to a point mutation (GAG to GUG in beta-globin gene, replacing glutamic acid with valine). Thalassemia is autosomal recessive with defective globin chain synthesis. NCERT Chapter 5.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Hormone):
(A) FSH
(B) LH
(C) Estrogen
(D) Progesterone

Column II (Primary function in females):
(i) Maintains endometrium during pregnancy
(ii) Stimulates follicular development
(iii) Triggers ovulation (LH surge)
(iv) Proliferation of endometrium; secondary sexual characters

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: FSH stimulates follicular development in ovaries. LH surge triggers ovulation. Estrogen causes proliferation of endometrium and development of secondary sexual characters. Progesterone maintains the endometrium during pregnancy (secreted by corpus luteum). NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Stage of spermatogenesis):
(A) Spermatogonium
(B) Primary spermatocyte
(C) Secondary spermatocyte
(D) Spermatid

Column II (Ploidy / Division):
(i) Haploid (n); transforms into spermatozoa by spermiogenesis
(ii) Diploid (2n); stem cell; undergoes mitosis
(iii) Diploid (2n); undergoes meiosis I
(iv) Haploid (n); undergoes meiosis II

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Spermatogonium (2n) is the stem cell that divides by mitosis. Primary spermatocyte (2n) undergoes meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes. Secondary spermatocyte (n) undergoes meiosis II to form spermatids. Spermatids (n) transform into spermatozoa by spermiogenesis. NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Embryonic membrane):
(A) Amnion
(B) Chorion
(C) Yolk sac
(D) Allantois

Column II (Function):
(i) Forms chorionic villi; part of placenta
(ii) Fluid-filled sac protecting embryo
(iii) Waste storage; contributes to umbilical cord
(iv) Early site of blood cell formation

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Amnion is a fluid-filled sac that protects the embryo from desiccation and mechanical shock. Chorion forms chorionic villi that are part of placenta. Yolk sac is the early site of blood cell formation in human embryos. Allantois is involved in waste storage and contributes to the umbilical cord. NCERT Chapter 3.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Restriction enzyme):
(A) EcoRI
(B) HindIII
(C) BamHI
(D) Sau3A

Column II (Source organism):
(i) Bacillus amyloliquefaciens
(ii) Staphylococcus aureus
(iii) Escherichia coli
(iv) Haemophilus influenzae

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: EcoRI comes from Escherichia coli RY13. HindIII comes from Haemophilus influenzae Rd. BamHI comes from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens H. Sau3A comes from Staphylococcus aureus 3A. The naming convention uses the first letter of genus and first two of species. NCERT Chapter 11.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Vector feature):
(A) ori (origin of replication)
(B) Selectable marker
(C) Cloning site
(D) Promoter for insert

Column II (Function):
(i) Ensures expression of cloned gene
(ii) Controls copy number; enables replication in host
(iii) Site where foreign DNA is inserted (restriction site)
(iv) Helps identify recombinant from non-recombinant

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: ori controls the copy number of linked DNA and enables autonomous replication. Selectable markers (like antibiotic resistance genes) help identify recombinants using insertional inactivation. Cloning site is where foreign DNA is inserted by restriction enzymes. Promoter ensures expression/transcription of the cloned gene. NCERT Chapter 11.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (rDNA tool):
(A) Gel electrophoresis
(B) PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction)
(C) Restriction endonuclease
(D) DNA ligase

Column II (Function):
(i) Joins DNA fragments (molecular glue)
(ii) Separates DNA fragments by size
(iii) Amplifies specific DNA segment in vitro
(iv) Cuts DNA at specific palindromic sequences

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size (smaller fragments move faster). PCR amplifies specific DNA segments using Taq polymerase. Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific palindromic sequences. DNA ligase joins DNA fragments together (acts as molecular glue). NCERT Chapter 11.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Microbe):
(A) Lactobacillus
(B) Saccharomyces cerevisiae
(C) Acetobacter aceti
(D) Propionibacterium shermanii

Column II (Product):
(i) Swiss cheese (large holes due to CO2)
(ii) Curd from milk
(iii) Ethanol (bread and beer making)
(iv) Vinegar (acetic acid)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Lactobacillus converts milk to curd (lactic acid fermentation). Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker's yeast) produces ethanol used in bread and beer making. Acetobacter aceti produces vinegar (acetic acid from ethanol). Propionibacterium shermanii produces CO2 that creates large holes in Swiss cheese. NCERT Chapter 10.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Antibiotic / Bioactive molecule):
(A) Penicillin
(B) Cyclosporin A
(C) Statin (Lovastatin)
(D) Streptokinase

Column II (Source / Use):
(i) Streptococcus; used as clot buster
(ii) Penicillium notatum; antibacterial
(iii) Trichoderma polysporum; immunosuppressant
(iv) Monascus purpureus; lowers cholesterol

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Penicillin was discovered from Penicillium notatum by Alexander Fleming; it is antibacterial. Cyclosporin A is from Trichoderma polysporum; used as immunosuppressant in organ transplants. Statin (Lovastatin) from Monascus purpureus lowers blood cholesterol. Streptokinase from Streptococcus is used as a clot buster. NCERT Chapter 10.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Process):
(A) Primary sewage treatment
(B) Secondary sewage treatment
(C) Biogas production
(D) Biocontrol of pests

Column II (Feature):
(i) Methanobacterium in anaerobic sludge digester
(ii) Physical removal of particles (filtration, sedimentation)
(iii) Biological treatment; aeration in aeration tank
(iv) Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) toxin genes

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Primary sewage treatment involves physical removal of particles by filtration and sedimentation. Secondary treatment is biological, involving aeration to promote aerobic microbial decomposition. Biogas production uses Methanobacterium in anaerobic sludge digesters. Biocontrol uses Bt toxin genes from Bacillus thuringiensis. NCERT Chapter 10.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Concept):
(A) Homologous organs
(B) Analogous organs
(C) Vestigial organs
(D) Connecting link

Column II (Example):
(i) Wings of bat and wings of insect
(ii) Forelimbs of whale and human hand
(iii) Archaeopteryx (reptiles and birds)
(iv) Vermiform appendix in humans

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Homologous organs have same origin but different functions (whale flipper and human hand). Analogous organs have different origin but similar function (bat wing and insect wing). Vestigial organs are non-functional remnants (vermiform appendix). Archaeopteryx is a connecting link between reptiles and birds. NCERT Chapter 7.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Geological Era):
(A) Palaeozoic
(B) Mesozoic
(C) Cenozoic
(D) Azoic (Precambrian)

Column II (Key event):
(i) Age of mammals; human evolution
(ii) First life (prokaryotes); stromatolites
(iii) Age of reptiles/dinosaurs; first birds
(iv) First amphibians; first seed plants

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Palaeozoic era saw the first amphibians and first seed plants. Mesozoic era was the age of reptiles/dinosaurs and first birds. Cenozoic era is the age of mammals including human evolution. Precambrian/Azoic era had the first prokaryotic life and stromatolites. NCERT Chapter 7.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Type of natural selection):
(A) Stabilizing selection
(B) Directional selection
(C) Disruptive selection
(D) Artificial selection

Column II (Feature / Example):
(i) Favours two extreme phenotypes; may lead to speciation
(ii) Favours average/intermediate phenotype
(iii) Human selection for desired traits (e.g., dog breeds)
(iv) Favours one extreme phenotype; shifts mean

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Stabilizing selection favours the average phenotype and reduces variation. Directional selection favours one extreme phenotype, shifting the population mean. Disruptive selection favours both extreme phenotypes and can lead to speciation. Artificial selection is human-directed selection for desired traits (e.g., dog breeds, crop varieties). NCERT Chapter 7.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Ecological term):
(A) GPP (Gross Primary Productivity)
(B) NPP (Net Primary Productivity)
(C) Secondary productivity
(D) Standing crop

Column II (Definition):
(i) GPP minus respiration (available for consumers)
(ii) Mass of living material at a given time
(iii) Rate of organic matter produced by consumers
(iv) Total rate of photosynthetic production including respiration

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: GPP is the total rate of photosynthesis including what is used in respiration. NPP = GPP - Respiration (available to consumers). Secondary productivity is the rate of formation of new organic matter by consumers. Standing crop is the mass of living material present at a particular time. NCERT Chapter 14.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Biogeochemical cycle):
(A) Carbon cycle
(B) Nitrogen cycle
(C) Phosphorus cycle
(D) Sulphur cycle

Column II (Key feature):
(i) No gaseous phase; sedimentary cycle
(ii) Nitrogen fixation by Rhizobium; denitrification
(iii) Volcanic eruptions; acid rain (SO2)
(iv) Fossil fuel combustion; ocean reservoir

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Carbon cycle involves fossil fuel combustion and ocean is a major reservoir. Nitrogen cycle involves nitrogen fixation by Rhizobium and denitrification. Phosphorus cycle is sedimentary with no gaseous phase. Sulphur cycle involves volcanic eruptions releasing SO2 and acid rain. NCERT Chapter 14.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Ecological pyramid):
(A) Pyramid of numbers — grassland
(B) Pyramid of numbers — parasitic food chain
(C) Pyramid of biomass — aquatic ecosystem
(D) Pyramid of energy

Column II (Shape):
(i) Always upright (10% energy transfer)
(ii) Inverted (phytoplankton < zooplankton biomass at any time)
(iii) Inverted (parasites more numerous than host)
(iv) Upright (grasses > herbivores > carnivores)

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: In grassland, pyramid of numbers is upright (many grasses, fewer herbivores, fewest carnivores). In parasitic food chains, parasites are more numerous than hosts (inverted). In aquatic ecosystems, pyramid of biomass is inverted because phytoplankton reproduce rapidly. Pyramid of energy is always upright (only 10% energy transfers to next level). NCERT Chapter 14.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Conservation type):
(A) In-situ conservation
(B) Ex-situ conservation
(C) Biodiversity hotspot
(D) Sacred groves

Column II (Example):
(i) Western Ghats, Indo-Burma, Himalaya
(ii) National parks, wildlife sanctuaries, biosphere reserves
(iii) Khasi and Jaintia hills (Meghalaya)
(iv) Zoological gardens, seed banks, botanical gardens

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: In-situ conservation protects species in their natural habitat (national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, biosphere reserves). Ex-situ conservation protects species outside their habitat (zoos, seed banks, botanical gardens). India has 4 biodiversity hotspots including Western Ghats, Indo-Burma, Himalaya, and Sundaland. Sacred groves in Khasi and Jaintia hills of Meghalaya are traditional conservation areas. NCERT Chapter 15.

questions.question:
Match the following columns:
Column I (Cause of biodiversity loss — Evil Quartet):
(A) Habitat loss and fragmentation
(B) Over-exploitation
(C) Alien species invasion
(D) Co-extinctions

Column II (Example):
(i) Nile perch in Lake Victoria
(ii) Dodo (Mauritius) — extinction by hunting
(iii) Amazon rainforest — deforestation
(iv) Host-specific parasites dying with host

Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation: Habitat loss: Amazon deforestation is the primary cause of biodiversity loss. Over-exploitation: Dodo was hunted to extinction. Alien species: Nile perch introduced in Lake Victoria caused extinction of native cichlid fish. Co-extinctions: when a host species goes extinct, its obligate parasites also go extinct. NCERT Chapter 15.
